diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,769 @@
+package tensorflow
+
+import (
+	"encoding/binary"
+	"fmt"
+	"math"
+	"reflect"
+	"runtime"
+	"unsafe"
+
+	"github.com/golang/protobuf/proto"
+
+	pb "github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/tensorflow/contrib/go/proto"
+)
+
+import "C"
+
+const (
+	cAckByte  = 6
+	cBellByte = 7
+	cDc1      = 17
+
+	cBytesComplex64 = 8
+	cBytesFloat32   = 4
+	cBytesFloat64   = 8
+	cBytesInt16     = 2
+	cBytesInt32     = 4
+	cBytesInt64     = 8
+	cBytesUint16    = 2
+)
+
+// A DataType represents the type of the data contained in a Tensor
+type DataType pb.DataType
+
+// A TensorInterface is the interface implemented by Tensors.
+type TensorInterface interface {
body:
(Just to bring in history, when I looked at this, we had previously discussed "Tensorable" or something like that to follow the naming convention, but it seemed awkward.  The typical convention is to name interfaces "-er", and I like the idea of a Tensor being a concrete type.  Tensorer doesn't make sense grammatically.  I didn't have any brilliant ideas for this one.)

Given all that, perhaps we should just delete it.  After all, we don't have multiple competing Tensor implementations yet, so perhaps a Tensor is just a Tensor. :)

I suspect that what we'll find with experience is that _either_ the user really wants a Tensor, or they want something with a subset of the Tensor methods, and will want a duck-typing interface for just that subset.

My vote is thus for getting rid of the interface for now.

Given all that, perhaps we should just delete it. After all, we don't have multiple competing Tensor implementations yet, so perhaps a Tensor is just a Tensor. :)

I suspect that what we'll find with experience is that either the user really wants a Tensor, or they want something with a subset of the Tensor methods, and will want a duck-typing interface for just that subset.

My vote is thus for getting rid of the interface for now.
body_text:
(Just to bring in history, when I looked at this, we had previously discussed "Tensorable" or something like that to follow the naming convention, but it seemed awkward.  The typical convention is to name interfaces "-er", and I like the idea of a Tensor being a concrete type.  Tensorer doesn't make sense grammatically.  I didn't have any brilliant ideas for this one.)
Given all that, perhaps we should just delete it.  After all, we don't have multiple competing Tensor implementations yet, so perhaps a Tensor is just a Tensor. :)
I suspect that what we'll find with experience is that either the user really wants a Tensor, or they want something with a subset of the Tensor methods, and will want a duck-typing interface for just that subset.
My vote is thus for getting rid of the interface for now.
